Darius founded the “Knights of the East,” after - wards known, on account of the color on their ban - ners, as the “Knights of the Red Cross,” and formed one of the appendant Orders of the Temple. The historical circumstances connected with the Order will be found in Josephus, and in the third and fourth chapters of 1st Esdras. “Sir Knights of St. John, of Jerusalem,” were founded in 1048, and in 1209 were called “Knights of Rhodes,” and In 1530 Emperor Charles V bestowed upon them the Island of Malta, and tliey have ever since been known as tbe “Knights of Malta.” The color of their uniform is black. This is also one of the appendant Orders of the Temple “Knights Templar” or “Knights of the Temple,” whose uniform was white, was founded for tlie res - cue of our Savior’s tomb from the Moslems and they captured Jerusalem in 1099, and bound themselves to keep Ihe way open for pilgrims to the Holy City, and they were then called the “Poor Fellow Soldiers of Jesus Christ.” In 1118 Baldwin I, King of Jerusalem, gave them a Chapel on the site of the old Temple, wlience they were called the “Poor Fellow Soldiers of Christ and of the Temple of Solomon,” and chose Hugh de Pay- ens as their leader, under the title of “Master of the Temple.” In 1128 they received their first regula - tions from the Pope, drawn up by St. Bernard, and continued to be governed by the noblest and bravest —3—

After the burning at the stake of Jacques de Molay, the Grand Lvlasters were generally selected from among the most influential noblemen of France, until 1838, when the office passed to Sir Sidney Smith, of England. Baldwin Commandery, of England, was establish - ed at Bristol, by the Knights who returned from Palestine with Richard I, from which, with Command - eries at Bath and York, was derived the material of the Order in this country. The first grand encampment of the United States was formed by a convention of eight encampments, June 22, 1816, with the Honorable and Sir DeWitt Clinton as first Grand Master. The first Grand Commandery for the State of Mis - souri was formed by representation from St. Louis Commandery, No. 1, and the Commanderies at Lex - ington and Weston, December 5, 1859, with Sir George W. Belt as the first Right Eminent Grand Command - er. Under a dispensation dated April 1, 1872, granted by Right Eminent F’. M. Tufts, Grand Commander of Missouri, the following Sir Knights: Sir Fred King, Eminent Commander; Sir Washington Galland, Gen - eralissimo; Sir Charles H. D. 1872, this Commandery received its Charter. —4— BY-LAWS St JOHN’S COMMANDERY NO.20 KNIGHTS TEMPLAR SPRINGFIELD, MO. ARTICLE I. Name. Section 1. This Commandery shall be known as St. John’s Commandery No. 20, Knights Templar, and Appendant Orders, stationed at Springfield, Mis - souri, U. S. A. ARTICLE II. Officers and Elections. Section 1. The officers shall be: Commander; Gen - eralissimo; Captain General; Senior Warden; Junior Warden; Prelate; Treasurer; Recorder; Standard Bearer; Sword Bearer; Warder; Sentinel. To which may be added three Guards and an Organist. Section 2 The Commander, Genegalissimo, Cap - tain General, Senior Warden, Junior Warden, Pre - late, Treasurer, and Recorder shall be elected by ballot at the first stated conclave in December of each year. A majority of all votes present shall be necessary to a choice, and no blank ballot shall be counted, The Standard Bearer, Sword Bearer, Ward - er, Sentinel, Guards and Organist shall be appointed by the Commander elect. T Section 3. All elected and appointed officers, when installed, shall hold their offices for a period of one year, or until their successors are elected or ap - pointed and installed. Section 4. The Commander, Generalissimo and Captain General shall constitute a Board of Trus - —5—

ARTICLE VI. Life Membership. Section 1. Any member of this Commandery may at any time, purchase a life membership, exempting him from further payment of dues, upon the pay - ment of One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) in cash; or, when he has paid dues to this Commandery for twenty-five (25) consecutive years, he may secure such life membership on payment of Twenty-five Dol - lars ($25.00) in cash; Provided, that he shall not be In arrears at the time of taking out said life mem - ~bership. r r Section 2. Nothing hereinafter contained shall be construed to prevent a life member from taking his dimit; but when a dimit is granted to a Life Mem - ber it is agreed and accepted by him that he volun - tarily relinquishes all his rights and interests in the payment made therefor. ARTICLE VIII. • Trcais. Penalties. Section 1. The manner and form of trials and ap - peals shall be as provided by the Grand Commandery of Missouri. When a Knight Templar is on trial for unknightly conduct, it shall require a three- fourths vote to establish guilt, and a majority vote to fix the penalty. The penalty for unknightly con - duct shall be expulsion, indefinite suspension, defi - nite suspension, or reprimand. When a Knight Tem - plar has been expelled or suspended for unknightly conduct he may be restored to good standing and membership upon petition and unanimous ballot. Section 3. Whenever a member shall neglect to pay his dues after the same become delinquent, the Recorder, by order of the Commander, shall notify each member in writing to appear at a stated con - clave of the Commandery and show cause why he should not be suspended for non-payment of dues. Should the member fail to appear and show cause, he may be suspended by a majority vote of the Coin - mandery. Such vote shall be by paper ballot. The Recorder shall serve such notice to appear and show cause ten days before the conclave, at which the member is to appear by registered letter addressed to the last known address of such delinquent. But should the residence of the member he unknown, or if he does not reside within the city of Springfield, Mo., such notice shall he sent to the last known post office address of such member, twonty days be - fore the date of the trial at which he is required to appear. Payment of dues before ballot shall stop all proceedings, and if paid within one year after suspension it shall restore to membership without further action If paid after one year from date of suspension it shall require a petition and majority vote to restore to membership I I ARTICLE IX. The price of uniforms to the Command - ery, in~luding coats, shall not exceed Fifty-two Dol - lars ($52 00). All uniforms shall be of the same style, quality, kind of goods, swords, etc. and of the same price as fixed by the Trustees. No member shall be allowed accessories, except as rank may entitle, nor shall members be permitted to pay for any extras to uniform. Section 3. Every member of this Command ery must be absolute owner, and in possession of, the regulation uniform and equipment, and must keel) himself so supplied while he remains a member. Failing to do so he shall be suspended, and shall remain suspended until he complies with this by - law. S?ction 4.
